COVID-19 has drastically altered our lives in an unprecedented manner, shuttering industries, 8 and leaving most of the country in isolation as we adapt to the evolving crisis. Orthopedic 9 surgery has not been spared from these effects, with the postponement of elective procedures 10 in an attempt to mitigate disease transmission and preserve hospital resources as the pandemic 11 continues to expand. During these turbulent times, it is crucial to understand that while patient 12 and care-providers safety is paramount, canceling or postponing essential surgical care is not 13 without consequences, and may be irreversibly detrimental to a patient's health and quality of 14 life in some cases. The optimal solution of how to effectively balance the resumption of 15 standard surgical care while doing everything possible to limit the spread of COVID-19 is 16 undetermined, and could include strategies such as social distancing, screening forms and tests 17

including temperature screening, segregation of inpatient and outpatient teams, proper use of 18 protective gear, and the use of ambulatory surgery centers (ASCs) to provide elective, yet 19 ultimately essential, surgical care while conserving resources and protecting the health of 20 patients and health-care providers. Of importance, these recommendations do not and should 21 not supersede evolving United States Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), and 22 relevant federal, state and local public health guidelines. Level of Evidence: Level V. 23 24
Introduction 25
The first confirmed case in the United States was reported in Northern Washington on January 26 20 th of this year. Since then, 2019 Novel Coronavirus (COVID-19) has upended our society and 27
placed an unprecedented strain on health-care systems across the country. 1 Orthopedic surgery 28

has not been spared from these drastic changes, particularly when considering the widespread 29 cessation of elective clinical and surgical care. Most of these elective procedures have been 30 postponed in the interest of patient and provider health, and to address anticipated shortages 31 in staffing, beds, ventilators, and personal protective equipment (PPE) as the virus rapidly 32 spreads through our communities. 2 This mandate effectively halted the traditional clinical 33 structure of orthopedic practices, necessitating a new system for providing the highest quality 34 of orthopedic care while practicing the principles of social distancing and preventative 35 measures to prevent the transmission of COVID-19. While a shift to telemedicine has proven 36 instrumental in providing care, questions about what is defined as an essential procedure have 37 come to the forefront. A preeminent concern in this conversation is how delays in care, 38 resulting in daily pain, functional disability, and unbearable financial damages will affect the 39 long-term physical and mental health, employment capacity, and overall wellbeing of patients 40 and our economy. Experiences in Hong Kong and Singapore have shown that mitigation 41 strategies like social distancing, temperature screenings, inpatient/outpatient teams, and the 42 use of ambulatory surgery centers (ASCs) have been effective for providing essential surgical 43 care while conserving resources and protecting the health of patients and health-care 44
providers. 3 45 46

The purpose of this investigation will be to present and analyze the most up-to-date available 47 evidence on how the COVID-19 pandemic has affected the orthopedic community. We will 48 present relevant evidence-based literature from the 2002-2004 Severe Acute Respiratory 49 Syndrome (SARS) outbreak. We will dive into the struggle between resuming state-of-the-art 50 surgical care, while maintaining social distancing and using all precautions to limit the spread of 51 COVID-19. We will explore pertinent terminology such as "elective", "emergent", "urgent", and 52

"essential/non-essential" surgery. Lastly, we will discuss and recommend guardrails to allow the 53 continuation of best practices and high-quality patient care, while maintaining patient and staff 54
safety. Keywords included combinations of the following terms: "COVID-19", "Corona Virus", "Severe 77
Acute Respiratory Syndrome", and "SARS" in conjunction with "Surgery", "Orthopedics", and 78

"Elective/emergent/urgent procedures". Importantly, no transmission was reported 104 between hospital staff. They also reported that there was no use of negative pressure or N95 105 masks in their facilities and that simple protective measures and strictly enforced safety 106 protocols are sufficient to control the in-hospital spread of SARS. 7 While Li et al. did not deem 107 the use of N95 masks and negative-pressure isolation rooms necessary, the Canadian 108 experience reported the following protective measures recommended: the use of negative-109 pressure isolation rooms where available; N95 or higher level of respiratory protection; gloves, 110 gowns, and eye protection; and careful hand hygiene. 8 Simple PPEs were also found to be 111 effective in a systematic review performed by Jefferson et al. and published in 2007. 9 Chu et al. 112 investigated the impact of SARS on hospital performance in Taipei, Taiwan. 10 They reported the 113 average monthly number of outpatient visits at base year was 52317 ± 4204. and surface stability, are transmitted by droplets, contact with infected persons and surfaces, 122

and both target the Angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE)-2 receptor. 12, 13 While the COVID-19 123 transmission rate seems much higher, case fatality rate is estimated to be less than 2.3% and 124 perhaps much lower. In comparison, SARS-CoV and Middle East respiratory syndrome (MERS)-125
CoV have a reported case fatality rate of 9.6% and 35%, respectively. 12, 14 126

The many recommendations put forth raise some essential considerations as orthopedic 166

surgeons adjust to the likely long-term impact that COVID-19 will have on surgical care. In this 167 early period, with thousands of deaths occurring each day and health systems still under 168 extreme stress, the decision to postpone elective procedures and allocate all resources towards 169 the crisis has been clear. However, now that conditions have seemingly started to stabilize in 170 certain regions, surgeons must weigh the relative risks of resuming their essential elective 171 practice while taking all possible precautions to limit COVID-19 spread. This should only be 172 performed following the White House and CDC "Opening Up America Again" guidelines, as well 173 as relevant federal, state, and local public health guidance. 21 Currently, the resumption of 174 elective procedures is planned to proceed during Phase I of the three-phase approach of the 175 "Opening Up America Again" initiative. 176 177
Moving Forward 178
The Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation at the University of Washington is supplying up 179

to date projections on COVID-19 including deaths per day, total deaths, and hospital resource 180 use. 22 The projections take into account the "stay at home order", closure of educational 181 facilities and non-essential services, and severe travel limitations, implemented on different 182 dates in different states. While the projections change with time, it appears the outbreak has 183 already peaked in many states and that many states will not sustain a deficit in hospital 184 resources. 185 186

These projections support the motion to responsibly and gradually lift the ban on essential 187 elective surgery worldwide. Lifting the constraints should not be done carelessly, and many 188 factors should be taken into account, including the regional health-care resources available and 189 the projection for a peak in transmissions and deaths in specific geographic regions. The 190 resumption of shoulder, knee, and ankle arthroscopies (and other orthopedics procedures 191 requiring ≤23 hours of hospital stay) in Singapore can be used as an example. 23 192
Consistent with the need to provide additional essential services, the White House and CDC are 193 currently supporting the reopening of elective surgery during Phase I. This also includes social 194

distancing, return to work in stages, resumption of elective surgeries, opening of gyms, while 195 schools and organized youth activities will remain closed. 196 197 This also proposes the formulation of region-specific plans how to operationally resume the 198 practice of patient care, as well as how to financially survive during these turbulent times. • Healthy asymptomatic patient 215

The patient must understand the possibility of an additional risk that entails being operated on 217 during the COVID-19 outbreak and provide written informed consent that speaks to the 218 necessity and risks and benefits of receiving care at this time. In addition, the surgical 219 management algorithms should be considered in the context of hospital-based inpatient 220
procedures on the one-hand and outpatient-based procedures commonly conducted in 221 ambulatory surgical centers (ASCs). 222 223

Initially, ASCs are perhaps the best facilities to be used in this setting, as most do not include an 224 emergency department or departments that typically admit elderly patients with infectious 225 diseases and/or severe co-morbidities. Moreover, most are currently vacant and had not been 226 transitioned to receive COVID-19 patients, as there was no need in most states to date. 227 228 We should remember that while removing these constraints, it will be critical to track any 229 suspicion for a local surge in infections and immediately contain the local outbreak with all 230 means, including immediate reporting to all relevant authorities. 231 232
Definition of Types of Surgery 233
One key consideration is the distinction between "essential" and "non-essential". Initial 234 recommendations in mid-March in the United States were primarily focused on managing 235

disease burden, such that the hospital system in general would not be overwhelmed in terms of 236 available resources including PPE, ventilators, and manpower. In addition, the benefits of 237 mitigation and social distancing were emphasized to meet that same goal. Thus, "elective 238
surgery" was determined to be "non-essential". Subsequently, discussions ensued that related 239
to activities that are essential with "emergent" procedures being the most clearly defined. 240

Interchangeably, the terms including "urgent" were utilized often referring to conditions that if 241 left untreated over some subsequent period of time (i.e, 4-6 weeks), the outcome of neglecting 242 that condition would have a negative impact on the patient's condition. Urgent conditions 243 would implicitly include those that are also considered emergent conditions, but arguably, 244

there is latitude depending upon tangible and intangible considerations to discuss what other 245 conditions would fall into the urgent category. The 4-6 week time line was essentially based 246 upon expectations for a greater clarity related to changes in disease burden and the effects of 247 mitigation and social distancing with some additional insights into the timing and duration of 248 "stay at home" orders. Notably, these same discussions have evolved to consider local demands 249 of the disease burden on the hospital system rather than the global impact of the disease state 250 on the entire hospital or medical system. 251 252

Some states have provided additional guidance. The Illinois Department of Public Health, for 253 example, defined elective procedures as those that are pre-planned by both the patient and the 254 physician, are advantageous to the patient, but are not urgent or emergent. As such, sports 255 medicine and orthopedic procedures in many institutions during this crisis have been limited to 256 those thought to be urgent or emergent, such as acute tendon injury, ligamentous tears, bucket 257 handle meniscus tear with a locked knee, intra-articular loose bodies causing acute symptoms, 258 acute fracture management, dislocated joints that cannot be closed reduced, infected joints 259 among several others. Expanding on these definitions which are relatively easy to define as 260 emergent conditions requiring relatively immediate treatment (as a class of essential services), 261 has included discussions related to conditions that are urgent (short of being emergent) 262

whereby surgical intervention is required to otherwise avoid worsening the condition should 263 surgery be delayed. Related to this is the further consideration that pain, dysfunction, and loss 264 of occupation can relate to the concept of urgency for an individual patient and thus, essential 265 provision of timely care may be indicated. 266 267

Other states have provided guidance on what to consider as essential or non-essential at the 268 discretion of licensed providers. In Ohio, for example, non-essential surgery is defined as a 269 procedure that can be delayed without undue risk to the current or future health of a patient. 270
However, in areas where resources are available and health systems are adequately equipped 271

to handle an uptick in COVID-19 cases, it may be appropriate to broaden the definitions of 272 essential procedures. As an example, outpatient hip, knee, and shoulder arthroscopies produce 273 little burden on hospital resources and can be reliably performed at outpatient ambulatory 274 surgery centers. 23 In these cases, postponing care may needlessly prolong patient pain, 275 disability, and loss of occupation. 276 277
While most would agree on what is an urgent or emergent orthopedic condition requiring 278
surgical intervention, broadening the definition of essential surgery may be more difficult and 279
subjective. Furthermore, practice patterns today will likely be in place for the foreseeable 280 future and "living with COVID" will continue to guide our policies and procedures.

Summary: 323 "First, do no harm" is embedded in our core as health care providers in addition to the privilege 324 to help those in need. We must limit all unnecessary activities to mitigate the harmful effects of 325 this pandemic. At the same time, we must remember that in our profession, failure to act and 326 provide essential care can be irreversibly detrimental to the patient's health and quality of life. 327

Whether the COVID-19 outbreak is close to an end, if the outbreak will reemerge next winter, 328 or if another contagious pathogen will appear, is unknown. However, it is clear that we must 329 adapt and find the way to resume our lives, providing high-quality medical and surgical care 330 while utilizing the best protective measures available to protect our patients and staff. 331 332 333

While a lower case fatality rate may also be attributed to inherent viral 129 characteristics, other contributing factors may include the improvement of health care services 130 and protective equipment, and other significant protective measures taken worldwide. 131 In summary, the 2002-2004 SARS outbreak teaches us that health care workers are at high-risk 132 and that PPEs and their proper utilization is essential. It is concerning that the current 133 pandemic may reemerge next winter and that recovery of health care services may take several 134 years or longer. 135 136 Review of the National and Regional Guidelines 137 By the time that the World Health Organization (WHO) declared COVID-19 a global pandemic 138 on March 11 th , it was apparent that the virus would place substantial strain on health care 139 infrastructure and supplies throughout the country in the following days and weeks. 15 To meet 140 these challenges, on March 13 th the American College of Surgeons (ACS) put forth the first 141 recommendations on elective care during this crisis. They recommended each surgeon to 142 "thoughtfully review all scheduled elective procedures with a plan to minimize, postpone, or 143 cancel electively scheduled operations." They also stated this recommendation be in place until 144 we have passed the anticipated inflection point of virus exposure and can reliably support a 145 rapid uptick in patient critical care needs. 16 This statement was quickly supported by the US 146 Surgeon General and followed-up by the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services (CMS), who 147 provided a tiered framework when considering elective medical services. 17, 18 The three tiers, 148which are based upon acuity, guide which procedures are appropriate to be conducted at this 149 time and which should be postponed.
